article.title: Dehydroepiandrosterone
article.paragraph: Dehydroepiandrosterone/dehydroepiandrostenedione(DHEA, more correctlydidehydroepiandrosterone), also known asandrostenoloneorprasterone(International Nonproprietary NameINN), as well as3-hydroxyandrost-5-en-17-oneor5-androsten-3-ol-17-one, is an importantendogenoussteroid hormone.cite journalMo Q, Lu SF, Simon NGDehydroepiandrosterone and its metabolites: differential effects on androgen receptor trafficking and transcriptional activityJ. Steroid Biochem. Mol. Biol.99150–8April 20061652471910.1016/j.jsbmb.2005.11.011http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0960-0760(06)00039-2It is the most abundant circulatingsteroidhormone in humans,William F Ganong MD, 'Review of Medical Physiology', 22nd Ed, McGraw Hill, 2005, page 362.in whom it is produced in theadrenal glands,The Merck Index, 13th Edition,7798thegonads, and thebrain,cite bookSchulman, Robert A.Dean, Carolyn2007Solve It With SupplementsRodale, Inc.New York City100978-1-57954-942-8DHEA (Dehydroepiandrosterone) is a common hormone produced in the adrenal glands, the gonads, and the brain.where it functions predominantly as ametabolic intermediatein thebiosynthesisof theandrogenandestrogensex steroids.cite bookThomas ScottConcise Encyclopedia Biologyhttp://books.google.com/books?id25 May 20121996Walter de Gruyter978-3-11-010661-949However, DHEA also has a variety of potential biological effects in its own right, binding to an array ofnuclear receptornuclearandcell surface receptors,cite journalWebb SJ, Geoghegan TE, Prough RA, Michael Miller KKThe biological actions of dehydroepiandrosterone involves multiple receptorsDrug Metabolism Reviews381–289–116200616684650242342910.1080/03602530600569877http://informahealthcare.com/doi/abs/10.1080/03602530600569877%20and acting as aneurosteroid.cite journalFriess E, Schiffelholz T, Steckler T, Steiger ADehydroepiandrosterone--a neurosteroidEuropean Journal of Clinical Investigation30 Suppl 346–50December 20001128136710.1046/j.1365-2362.2000.0300s3046.xhttp://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/resolve/openurl?genre
article.heading: Medical aspects
article.paragraph: In women withadrenal insufficiencyand the healthy elderly there is insufficient evidence to support the use of DHEA.cite journalArltWDehydroepiandrosterone and ageingBest practice & research. Clinical endocrinology & metabolismSeptember 2004183363–801526184310.1016/j.beem.2004.02.006cite journalAlkatibAACosma, MElamin, MBErickson, DSwiglo, BAErwin, PJMontori, VMA systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized placebo-controlled trials of DHEA treatment effects on quality of life in women with adrenal insufficiencyThe Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and MetabolismOctober 200994103676–811977340010.1210/jc.2009-0672
article.heading: Cancer
article.paragraph: There is no evidence DHEA is of benefit in treating or preventingcancer.
article.heading: Strength
article.paragraph: Evidence is inconclusive in regards to the effect of DHEA on strength in the elderly.cite journalBakerWLKaran, SKenny, AMEffect of dehydroepiandrosterone on muscle strength and physical function in older adults: a systematic reviewJournal of the American Geriatrics SocietyJune 2011596997–10022164961710.1111/j.1532-5415.2011.03410.x

In middle-aged men, no statistically significant effect of DHEA supplementation on lean body mass, strength, ortestosteronelevels was found in a randomized placebo-controlled trial.cite journalWallace, M. B.; Lim, J.; Cutler, A.; Bucci, L.Effects of dehydroepiandrosterone vs androstenedione supplementation in menMedicine and Science in Sports and Exercise31121788–9219991061342910.1097/00005768-199912000-00014
article.heading: Memory
article.paragraph: DHEA supplementation has not been found to be useful for memory function in normal middle aged or older adults.cite journalGrimley EvansJMalouf, RHuppert, Fvan Niekerk, JKDehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) supplementation for cognitive function in healthy elderly peopleCochrane database of systematic reviews (Online)Oct 18, 20064CD0062211705428310.1002/14651858.CD006221MaloufReemIt has been studied as a treatment forAlzheimer's disease, but there is no evidence that it is effective.cite journalFullerSJTan, RSMartins, RNAndrogens in the etiology of Alzheimer's disease in aging men and possible therapeutic interventionsJournal of Alzheimer's disease : JADSeptember 2007122129–4217917157
article.heading: Cardiovascular disease
article.paragraph: A review in 2003 found the then-extant evidence sufficient to suggest that low serum levels of DHEAS may be associated with coronary heart disease in men, but insufficient to determine whether DHEA supplementation would have any cardiovascular benefit.cite journal14609305585Are low dehydroepiandrosterone sulphate levels predictive for cardiovascular diseases? A review of prospective and retrospective studiesOctober 2003Acta Cardiol403–10Thijs L, Fagard R, Forette F, Nawrot T, Staessen JA10.2143/AC.58.5.2005304
article.heading: Lupus
article.paragraph: There is some evidence of short-term benefit in those withsystemic lupus erythematosusbut little evidence of long-term benefit or safety.cite journalCrosbieDBlack, CMcIntyre, LRoyle, PLThomas, SDehydroepiandrosterone for systemic lupus erythematosusCochrane database of systematic reviews (Online)Oct 17, 20074CD0051141794384110.1002/14651858.CD005114.pub2CrosbieDavid
article.heading: Body Composition
article.paragraph: A meta-analysis of intervention studies shows that DHEA supplementation in elderly men can induce a small but significant positive effect on body composition that is strictly dependent on DHEA conversion into its bioactive metabolites such as androgens or estrogens.Dehydroepiandrosterone supplementation in elderly men: a meta-analysis study of placebo-controlled trials. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23824417
article.heading: Side effects
article.paragraph: DHEA is produced naturally in the human body, but the long-term effects of its use are largely unknown.In the short term, several studies have noted few adverse effects. In a study by Changet al., DHEA was administered at a dose of 200 mg/day for 24 weeks with slightandrogeniceffects noted.cite journalChang DM, Lan JL, Lin HY, Luo SFDehydroepiandrosterone treatment of women with mild-to-moderate systemic lupus erythematosus: a multicenter randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trialArthritis Rheum200246112924–292710.1002/art.1061512428233Another study utilized a dose up to 400 mg/day for 8 weeks with few adverse events reported.cite journalRabkin JG, McElhiney MC, Rabkin R, McGrath PJ, Ferrando SJPlacebo-controlled trial of dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) for treatment of nonmajor depression in patients with HIV/AIDSAm J Psychiatry.2006163159–6610.1176/appi.ajp.163.1.5916390890A longer term study followed patients dosed with 50 mg of DHEA for 12 months with the number and severity of side effects reported to be small.cite journalBrooke AM, Kalingag LA, Miraki-Moud F, Camacho-Hübner C, Maher KT, Walker DM, Hinson JP, Monson JPDehydroepiandrosterone improves psychological well-being in male and female hypopituitary patients on maintenance growth hormone replacementJ Clin Endocrinol Metab200691103773–377910.1210/jc.2006-031616849414Another study delivered a dose of 50 mg of DHEA for 10 months with no serious adverse events reported.cite journalVillareal DT, Holloszy JODHEA enhances effects of weight training on muscle mass and strength in elderly women and menAm J Physiol Endocrinol Metab20062915E1003–100810.1152/ajpendo.00100.2006

As a hormone precursor, there has been a smattering of reports of side effects possibly caused by the hormone metabolites of DHEA.cite webhttp://www.medscape.com/druginfo/dosage?cidDHEA OralMedscape2010Drug ReferenceWebMD LLC.18 February 2010cite webhttp://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/druginfo/natural/patient-dhea.html#SafetyDHEAMedline PlusDrugs and Supplements InformationNational Library of Medicine18 February 2010

It is not known whether DHEA is safe for long-term use. Some researchers believe DHEA supplements might actually raise the risk ofbreast cancer,prostate cancer,heart disease,diabetes,andstroke. DHEA may stimulate tumor growth in types of cancer that are sensitive to hormones, such as some types of breast, uterine, and prostate cancer.DHEA may increase prostate swelling in men withbenign prostatic hyperplasia(BPH), an enlarged prostate gland.

DHEA is asteroid hormone. High doses may cause aggressiveness, irritability, trouble sleeping, and the growth of body or facial hair on women.It also may stop menstruation and lower the levels ofHigh-density lipoproteinHDL("good" cholesterol), which could raise the risk of heart disease.Other reported side effects include acne, heart rhythm problems, liver problems, hair loss (from the scalp), and oily skin. It may also alter the body's regulation of blood sugar.

DHEA should not be used withtamoxifen, as it may promote tamoxifen resistance.Patients on hormone replacement therapy may have more estrogen-related side effects when taking DHEA. This supplement may also interfere with other medicines, and potential interactions between it and drugs and herbs should be considered. Always tell your doctor and pharmacist about any supplements and herbs you are taking.cite book[[American Cancer Society]]American Cancer Society Complete Guide to Complementary and Alternative Cancer Therapies2nd20099780944235713Ades TB729–733DHEA

DHEA is possibly unsafe for individuals experiencing the following conditions: pregnancy and breast-feeding, hormone sensitive conditions, liver problems, diabetes, depression or mood disorders,polycystic ovarian syndrome(PCOS), or cholesterol problems.cite webDHEA: Side effects and safetyhttp://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-331-DHEA.aspx?activeIngredientIdWebMD24 July 2012Individuals experiencing any of these conditions should consult with a doctor before taking.
article.heading: Dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate
article.paragraph: MainDehydroepiandrosterone sulfateDehydroepiandrosterone sulfate(DHEAS) is the sulfate ester of DHEA. This conversion is reversibly catalyzed bysulfotransferase(SULT2A1) primarily in the adrenals, theliver, andsmall intestine. In the blood, most DHEA is found as DHEAS with levels that are about 300 times higher than those of free DHEA. Orally ingested DHEA is converted to its sulfate when passing through intestines and liver. Whereas DHEA levels naturally reach their peak in the early morning hours, DHEAS levels show noCircadian rhythmdiurnalvariation. From a practical point of view, measurement of DHEAS is preferable to DHEA, as levels are more stable.Citation neededJanuary 2009
article.heading: Production
article.paragraph: File:Steroidogenesis.svgthumbrightComprehensive overview ofsteroidogenesis, showing DHEA at left among the androgens.DHEA is produced from cholesterol through twocytochrome P450enzymes. Cholesterol is converted topregnenoloneby the enzymeP450 scc(side chaincleavage); then another enzyme,CYP17A1, convertspregnenoloneto17-Hydroxypregnenolone17-hydroxypregnenoloneand then to DHEA.Harper's illustrated Biochemistry, 27th edition, Ch.41 "The Diversity of the Endocrine system"
article.heading: Mechanism of action
article.paragraph: Although it predominantly functions as an endogenousprecursor (biochemistry)precursorto morepotency (pharmacology)potentandrogens such as testosterone and DHT, DHEA has been found to possess some degree ofandrogenicactivity in its own right, acting as a lowaffinity (pharmacology)affinity(Ki= 1 M), weakpartial agonistof theandrogen receptor. However, itsintrinsic activityat the receptor is quite weak, and on account of that, due tocompetitive inhibitioncompetitionformolecular bindingbindingwithfull agonistslike testosterone, it can actually behave more like an antagonist depending on circulating testosterone anddihydrotestosterone(DHT) levels, and hence, like anantiandrogen. However, its affinity for the receptor is very low, and for that reason, is unlikely to be of much significance under normal circumstances.cite journalChen F, Knecht K, Birzin EDirect agonist/antagonist functions of dehydroepiandrosteroneEndocrinology146114568–76November 20051599434810.1210/en.2005-0368http://endo.endojournals.org/cgi/pmidlookup?viewetalcite journalGao W, Bohl CE, Dalton JTChemistry and structural biology of androgen receptorChemical Reviews10593352–70September 200516159155209661710.1021/cr020456uhttp://dx.doi.org/10.1021/cr020456u

In addition to its affinity for the androgen receptor, DHEA has also been found to bind to and activate theEstrogen receptor alphaERandEstrogen receptor betaERestrogen receptorswith Kivalues of 1.1 M and 0.5 M, respectively, andEC50EC50values of >1 M and 200 nM, respectively. Though it was found to be a partial agonist of the ER with a maximal efficacy of 30-70%, the concentrations required for this degree of activation make it unlikely that the activity of DHEA at this receptor is physiologically meaningful. Remarkably however, DHEA acts as a full agonist of the ER with a maximal response similar to or actually slightly greater than that ofestradiol, and its levels in circulation and local tissues in the human body are high enough to activate the receptor to the same degree as that seen with circulating estradiol levels at somewhat higher than their maximal, non-ovulationovulatoryconcentrations; indeed, when combined with estradiol with both at levels equivalent to those of their physiological concentrations, overall activation of the ER was doubled. As such, it has been proposed that DHEA may be an important and potentially major endogenousestrogenin the body.

Unlike the case of the androgen and estrogen receptors, DHEA does not bind to or activate theprogesterone receptorprogesterone,glucocorticoid receptorglucocorticoid, ormineralocorticoid receptors.cite journalLindschau C, Kirsch T, Klinge U, Kolkhof P, Peters I, Fiebeler ADehydroepiandrosterone-induced phosphorylation and translocation of FoxO1 depend on the mineralocorticoid receptorHypertension583471–8September 20112174704110.1161/HYPERTENSIONAHA.111.171280http://hyper.ahajournals.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view

Othernuclear receptortargets of DHEA include thePeroxisome proliferator-activated receptorPPAR,pregnane X receptorPXR, andConstitutive androstane receptorCAR. In addition, it has been found to directly act on severalcell surface receptormembrane receptors, including theNMDA receptoras apositive allosteric modulator, theGABAA receptorGABAAreceptoras anegative allosteric modulator, and thesigma-1 receptor1receptoras anagonist. It is these actions that have conferred the label of a "neurosteroid" upon DHEA. Finally, DHEA is thought to regulate a handful of otherproteinsvia indirect, genomic mechanisms, including theenzymesCYP2C11P4502C11and11-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase type 111-HSD1the latter of which is essential for the biosynthesis of theglucocorticoidssuch ascortisoland has been suggested to be involved in theantiglucocorticoideffects of DHEAand theCarrier proteincarrierInsulin-like growth factor-binding protein 1IGFBP1.cite journalKalimi M, Shafagoj Y, Loria R, Padgett D, Regelson WAnti-glucocorticoid effects of dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA)Molecular and Cellular Biochemistry131299–104February 1994803578510.1007/BF00925945
article.heading: Biological role
article.paragraph: DHEA and other adrenal androgens such asandrostenedione, although relatively weak androgens, are responsible for the androgenic effects ofadrenarche, such as earlypubic hairpubicandaxillary hairgrowth, adult-typebody odor, increased oiliness of hair and skin, and mildacne.cite bookOra Hirsch PescovitzErica A. EugsterPediatric Endocrinology: Mechanisms, Manifestations, and Managementhttp://books.google.com/books?id2004Lippincott Williams & Wilkins978-0-7817-4059-3362–cite bookFima LifshitzPediatric Endocrinology: Growth, Adrenal, Sexual, Thyroid, Calcium, and Fluid Balance Disordershttp://books.google.com/books?id26 December 2006CRC Press978-1-4200-4272-6289–cite bookSudha SalhanTextbook of Gynecologyhttp://books.google.com/books?id1 August 2011JP Medical Ltd978-93-5025-369-494–Women withcomplete androgen insensitivity syndrome(CAIS), who have a non-functionalandrogen receptor(AR) and are immune to the androgenic effects of DHEA and other androgens, have absent or only sparse/scanty pubic and axillary hair andbody hairin general, demonstrating the role of DHEA,testosterone, and other androgens in body hair development at both adrenarche andpubarche.cite bookJ.P. LaveryJ.S. SanfilippoPediatric and Adolescent Obstetrics and Gynecologyhttp://books.google.com/books?id6 December 2012Springer Science & Business Media978-1-4612-5064-745–cite bookRobert L. NussbaumRoderick R. McInnesHuntington F WillardThompson & Thompson Genetics in Medicinehttp://books.google.com/books?id28 April 2015Elsevier Health Sciences978-0-323-39206-8102–cite bookMarcus E SetchellC. N. HudsonShaw's Textbook of Operative Gynaecologyhttp://books.google.com/books?id4 April 2013Elsevier Health Sciences81-312-3481-9129–cite bookBruno BissonnetteBernard DalensSyndromes: Rapid Recognition and Perioperative Implicationshttp://books.google.com/books?id20 July 2006McGraw Hill Professional978-0-07-135455-4184

As aneurosteroid, DHEA has important effects onneurologicalandpsychologicalfunctioning.cite bookAbraham WeizmanNeuroactive Steroids in Brain Function, Behavior and Neuropsychiatric Disorders: Novel Strategies for Research and Treatmenthttp://books.google.com/books?id1 February 2008Springer Science & Business Media978-1-4020-6854-6241–cite bookAchille G. GravanisSynthia H. MellonHormones in Neurodegeneration, Neuroprotection, and Neurogenesishttp://books.google.com/books?id24 June 2011John Wiley & Sons978-3-527-63397-5349–cite bookSex difference in the human brain, their underpinnings and implicationshttp://books.google.com/books?id3 December 2010Elsevier978-0-444-53631-0127–
article.heading: Measurement
article.paragraph: As almost all DHEA is derived from the adrenal glands, blood measurements of DHEAS/DHEA are useful to detect excess adrenal activity as seen in adrenal cancer or hyperplasia, including certain forms ofcongenital adrenal hyperplasia. Women withpolycystic ovary syndrometend to have elevated levels of DHEAS.cite journal482003Annales Academiae Medicae BialostocensisIncidence of elevated LH/FSH ratioin polycystic ovary syndrome women with normo- and hyperinsulinemiaBanaszewska B, Spaczyński RZ, Pelesz M, Pawelczyk L
article.heading: Increasing endogenous production
article.paragraph: Regularexerciseis known to increase DHEA production in the body.Cite journalEur. J. Appl. Physiol. Occup. Physiol.1998785466–47110.1007/s0042100504479809849FilaireEDuchéPLacGEffects of amount of training on the saliva concentrations of cortisol, dehydroepiandrosterone and on the dehydroepiandrosterone: Cortisol concentration ratio in women over 16 weeks of trainingCite journalJ. Gerontol. A. Biol. Sci. Med. Sci.2002574B158–16510.1093/gerona/57.4.B158Hormonal Responses to Endurance and Resistance Exercise in Females Aged 19-69 YearsCopelandJ. L.ConsittL. A.TremblayM. S.Calorie restrictionhas also been shown to increase DHEA in primates.Cite journalMattisonJulie A.LaneMark A.RothGeorge S.IngramDonald K.2003Calorie restriction in rhesus monkeysExperimental Gerontology381–235–4610.1016/S0531-5565(02)00146-812543259.Some theorize that the increase in endogenous DHEA brought about by calorie restriction is partially responsible for the longer life expectancy known to be associated with calorie restriction.Cite journalRobertsE.The importance of dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate in the blood of primates: a longer and healthier life?[[Biochemical Pharmacology]]1999574329–34610.1016/S0006-2952(98)00246-99933021.Catalpol and a combination of acetyl-carnitine and propionyl-carnitine on 1:1 ratio also improves endogenous DHEA production and release due to direct cholinergic stimulation of CRH release and an increase of IGF-1 expression respectively.
article.heading: Isomers
article.paragraph: The term "dehydroepiandrosterone" is ambiguous chemically because it does not include the specific positions within epiandrosterone at which hydrogen atoms are missing. DHEA has a number of naturally occurring isomers that may have similar pharmacological effects. Some isomers of DHEA are1-Dehydroepiandrosterone1-dehydroepiandrosteroneand4-Dehydroepiandrosterone4-dehydroepiandrosterone. These isomers are also technically DHEA, since they are dehydroepiandrosterones in which hydrogens are removed from theepiandrosteroneskeleton.
article.heading: Society and culture
Legality
United States
article.paragraph: DHEA is legal to sell in the United States as a dietary supplement. It is currentlyGrandfather clausegrandfatheredin as an "Old Dietary Ingredient" being on sale prior to 1994. DHEA is specifically exempted from the Anabolic Steroid Control Act of 1990 and 2004cite webhttp://www.deadiversion.usdoj.gov/fed_regs/rules/2005/fr1216.htmDrug Scheduling Actions - 2005[[Drug Enforcement Administration]]It is banned from use in athletic competition.
article.heading: Canada
article.paragraph: In Canada, DHEA is a Controlled Drug listed under Section 23 of Schedule IV of theControlled Drugs and Substances ActHealth Canada, DHEA listing in the Ingredient Databaseand as such is available by prescription only.
article.heading: Australia
article.paragraph: In Australia, a prescription is required to buy DHEA, where it is also comparatively expensive compared to off-the-shelf purchases in US supplement shops. Australian customs classify DHEA as an "anabolic steroid[s] or precursor[s]" and, as such, it is only possible to carry DHEA into the country through customs if one possesses an import permit which may be obtained if one has a valid prescription for the hormone.Therapeutic Goods Administration, Personal Importation Scheme
article.heading: Sports and athletics
article.paragraph: DHEA is a prohibited substance under the World Anti-Doping Code of the World Anti-Doping Agency,World Anti-Doping Agencywhich manages drug testing for Olympics and other sports. In January 2011,National Basketball AssociationNBAplayerO.J. Mayowas given a 10-game suspension after testing positive for DHEA. Mayo termed his use of DHEA as "an honest mistake," saying the DHEA was in anover-the-countersupplement and that he was unaware the supplement was banned by the NBA.Memphis Grizzlies' O.J. Mayo gets 10-game drug suspension,ESPN, January 27, 2011.Mayo is the seventh player to test positive for performance-enhancing drugs since the league began testing in 1999. Rashard Lewis, then with the Orlando Magic, tested positive for DHEA and was suspended 10 games before the start of the 2009-10 season.Memphis Grizzlies' O.J. Mayo suspended 10 games for violating NBA anti-drug program2008 Olympic 400 meter championLashawn Merritthas also tested positive for DHEA and was banned from the sport for 21 months.cite webhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/athletics/8638727.stmUS 400m star LaShawn Merritt fails drug test[[BBC Sport]]22 April 2010Yulia Efimova, Russian Olympic Medal-Winning Swimmer 2013, had positive test for DHEA.Russian Olympic Medal-Winning Swimmer Efimova Fails Doping Test Report
article.heading: Marketing
article.paragraph: In the United States, DHEA or DHEAS have been advertised with claims that they may be beneficial for a wide variety of ailments. DHEA and DHEAS are readily available in the United States, where they are marketed as over-the-counterdietary supplements.cite journalCalfee, R.; Fadale, P.Popular ergogenic drugs and supplements in young athletesPediatrics1173e577–89March 20061651063510.1542/peds.2005-1429In 2004, a new Steroid Control Act that placed androstenedione under Schedule III of controlled substances effective January 2005 was signed. DHEA was not included in this act and remains an over-the-counter nutritional supplement.

list.listitem: DHEA in elderly women and DHEA or testosterone in elderly men, published in theNew England Journal of Medicinein 2006. "Neither DHEA nor low-dose testosterone replacement in elderly people has physiologically relevant beneficial effects on body composition, physical performance, insulin sensitivity, or quality of life."
